Fig. 1 X-ray diffractograms for the SC support. The symbols refer to tridymite (∆), silicon carbide (▲) and graphitic carbon (□). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TGA and DTG profiles in Ar, air, and N₂ atmospheres for the dried catalysts: (a) Ni(Cl−)/SC (b) Ni(Ac−)/SC (c) Ni(NO3 −)/SC. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 FTIR spectra of the gases collected from the decomposition in different atmospheres of the dried catalysts (a) Ni(Cl−)/SC-Air (b) Ni(Cl−)/SCN2 (c) Ni(Cl−)/SC-Ar (d) Ni(Ac−)/SC-Air (e) Ni(Ac−)/SC-N2 (f) Ni(Ac−)/SC-Ar (g) Ni(NO3 −)/SC-Air (h) Ni(NO3 −)/SC-N2 (i) Ni(NO3 −)/SC-Ar. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 X-ray diffractograms for the catalysts dried and calcined in different atmospheres (Ar, Air, N2) (a) Ni(Cl−)/SC (b) Ni(Ac−)/SC (c) Ni(NO3 −)/SC. The symbols refer to trydimite (∆), graphitic carbon (□), SiC (▲), NiCl2·6H2O (●), Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (■), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (▼), NiO (★), Ni3N (♦). In this work, Ni catalysts supported on a SiO2 C (SC) material were prepared using different metal precursors (NiCl2·6H2O, Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) and calcination atmospheres (Ar, air and N2), to be applied in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol in liquid phase. The thermal decomposition of the precursors was studied by in situ TGA-FTIR, XRD and TPR, which allowed the determination of the Ni species formed and their degree of interaction with the support. After activation in H2 flow, the reduced catalysts were characterized by XRD and H2 chemisorption, which allowed the determination of their crystalline structure and particle size. All catalysts showed activity in the hydrogenolysis reaction with high selectivity to 1,2-propylene glycol (80–90 %) and low selectivity to CC bond cleavage products. The type of precursor and calcination atmosphere were found to influence Ni dispersion and Turnover Frequency (TOF) values, obtaining a correlation between catalytic activity and metal particle size. The results show that the TOF increases with increasing Ni particle size in the range of 2 to 17 nm. These results suggest that the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over Ni catalysts is a structure sensitive reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nickel Metallic precursor Catalysts Glycerol Hydrogenolysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, society has become increasingly aware of the environmental impact of using fossil fuels to produce energy and products for the chemical industry. This has encouraged the search for alternative sources to partially replace the current dependence on non-renewable sources. Within the biofuel market, biodiesel production is one of the most important worldwide, both due to its expansion in developed countries such as Germany, Italy, France and the United States, and in developing countries, mainly Argentina, Brazil, Indonesia and Malaysia [1]. The production of biodiesel yields glycerol as a by-product, a polyhydroxylated alcohol that is used in the chemical, pharmaceutical, polymer and food industries for the production of various products such as cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, resins, tobacco, detergents, etc. Due to the saturation of the glycerol market (because of its abundance, availability and low cost), the search for new alternatives for its transformation into products with high added value is very attractive [2]. Among the possible valorization reactions, catalytic hydrogenolysis, either in liquid or vapor phase, allows to obtain 1,2-propylene glycol (1,2-PG), a chemical product with high added value, used in the production of high strength polymers, resins, pharmaceutical products, cosmetics, etc. [3]. The mechanism of hydrogenolysis consists of CO and CC bond cleavage reactions and hydrogenation reactions leading to the formation of C1 products such as methanol (MeOH), C2 products such as ethylene glycol (EG) and ethanol (EtOH) and C3 products such as acetol (AcOH), 1,2-propylene glycol (1,2-PG), 1,3-propylene glycol (1,3-PG), 1-propanol (1-POH) and 2-propanol (2-POH) [4–8]. CO cleavage reactions require supports with acidic properties, while hydrogenation reactions require a suitable metal phase. Catalysts based on noble metals such as Ru, Pt and Pd have been studied and have shown high CC bond cleavage capabilities that promote EG and gas formation side reactions [9]. In contrast, non-precious metals such as Cu, Co and Ni are of great interest due to their low cost and higher ability to break CO bonds rather than CC bonds [10]. The metal precursor used in the preparation of the catalysts, as well as the preparation method and the calcination and activation pretreatments influence the activity level and selectivity. Regarding the precursors, in the case of Ru, the use of Ru(NO)(NO3)3 allowed to obtain a low selectivity to 1,2-PG in the hydrogenolysis with smaller Ru particles, and it was also found that the degradation products are structure sensitive [11]. Ru/C catalysts prepared with RuCl3 showed the highest yield on glycols with Ru particles of about 5 nm. These results suggest that the hydrogenolysis reaction may be structure sensitive [12]. Other precursors such as Ru(AcAc)3 and Ru3(CO)12 have been used less frequently and have shown lower levels of activity compared to the other precursors [13]. For Pd-based catalysts, PdCl2 [14–16], Pd(NO3)2 [15], Pd(AcO)2 [17] and Na2PdCl4 [17] have been used as precursors. For Pd/SBA-15 catalysts, the order of activity has been found to follow the trend: PdCl2 > Pd(NO3)2 ∼ Pd(AcO)2 [15]. In this case, the presence of Cl− from PdCl2 improves the reducibility of the catalyst, generating different particle sizes which could improve activity levels [16]. Regarding the preparation method, Balaraju et al. prepared Ru/TiO2 catalysts and found that the deposition-precipitation method allowed achieving a higher metal dispersion (29–53 %) than the incipient wetness impregnation method due to the reduction of Ru(OH)3 species, which resulted in obtaining metal particles with average particle sizes between 1 and 3 nm [18]. In the case of the preparation of Pd catalysts, the co-precipitation method has been found to be more efficient than the impregnation method because it produces metal-support interaction and therefore higher activity levels [19,20]. In this sense, Pd/Fe2O3 [19], PdO/CoO [19], Pd/Co3O4 [20] and Pd/Fe3O4 [20] catalysts prepared by co-precipitation were more active than those prepared by impregnation. For Cu catalysts supported on SiO2, the impregnation and coprecipitation methods produced better activity results compared to bulk Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Of the two methods, the coprecipitation method allowed a higher dispersion of Cu particles and a better metal-support interaction [21,22]. Other more sophisticated preparation methods have shown even better performance for the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Preparation by the hydrothermal ammonia evaporation method resulted in highly dispersed Cu0 nanoparticles interacting with Cu+ species, responsible for the catalytic performance [23]. Regarding calcination and activation pretreatments, Vila et al. studied calcination, reduction and oxidation steps on Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and found that the activity and selectivity towards 1,2-PG increased in the presence of Cu0 and Cu+ species, while Cu+2 species proved to be the least active [24]. The support also has an effect on activity levels, not only through its effect on particle size, but also through its textural and acid-base properties. Most work has used traditional inorganic oxides such as γ-Al2O3, MgO, SiO2 and SiO2-Al2O3, among others [25]. The main disadvantage of using these supports is their low thermal stability under reaction conditions, especially in the liquid phase, where they undergo deep transformations at the level of their crystalline and porous structure, which limits their application over time [26,27]. Carbonaceous supports, on the other hand, have been shown to have higher thermal stability as well as suitable textural properties that provide the necessary specific surface area for the formation of highly dispersed metal particles [28,29]. Of all the catalytic systems used in glycerol hydrogenolysis, those based on Ni have been least studied. The articles that have prepared and studied Ni-supported catalysts have mainly used Ni(NO3)2 as the precursor combined with the impregnation method [30], although the co-precipitation [31] and deposition– precipitation methods have also been reported [32]. The most used supports are based on activated carbon [33], SiO2 [34] and γ-Al2O3 [35]. Supported catalysts based on Ni as the active phase showed, in general, high selectivity to 1,2-PG, comparable to those obtained with supported catalysts based on Ru and other noble metals. With respect to other metal phases based on non-noble metals, commercial Ni/C catalysts were demonstrated to be as active and equally selective to 1,2-PG as Cu catalysts [36]. The same trend was observed for commercial Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts compared to CuCr2O4 catalysts; however, the selectivity towards CC bond cleavage was higher for the Ni catalyst [4]. Employing neutral supports, the formation of products depends exclusively on the structural characteristics of the Ni metal phase. This phenomenon occurs for example in Ni/SiO2 catalysts, which showed low activity (57 %) with low selectivity to 1,2-PG (44 %) under moderate reaction conditions at 200 °C, 6 MPa of H2 and 10 h [37]. The results obtained could be assigned to the ability of Ni to participate in CC bond cleavage reactions in the presence of a neutral support [34]. In previous research, our group synthesized a carbon-based composite (SiO2 C) that proved to be stable under the hydrothermal conditions of the hydrogenolysis reaction [38]. This material was used as support for the preparation of Ni catalysts based on chloride as the precursor salt, which proved to be active and selective in the production of 1,2-PG [39]. Although Ni catalysts have been used in glycerol hydrogenolysis, no studies have been reported on the effect of particle size by the type of precursor or by the calcination treatment used. This work aims to investigate the effect of the metal precursor and the calcination atmosphere on the activity of Ni catalysts prepared on the SiO2 C support and applied in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to obtain 1,2-PG in the liquid phase. The turnover frequency (TOF) values were determined and correlated with the average Ni particle size. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the support and catalysts The silica-carbon (SC) material used as a support was synthesized employing the raw materials and following the procedure described in a previous work [39]. Ni-based catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method, employing ethanol as the solvent. The Ni precursors used were: NiCl2·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 98 %), Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 98 %) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 98.5 %). In each case, the Ni precursor was dissolved in an ethanol volume equal to the pore volume of the support, and the solution was impregnated dropwise onto the support until forming a granular solid. The precursor concentration in ethanol was calculated to achieve 5 wt. % Ni in the final solid. The catalysts were denoted as Ni(Cl−)/SC, Ni(Ac−)/SC and Ni(NO3 −)/SC, depending on the precursor used for the preparation. The obtained solids were then dried in an oven at 105 °C for 12 h and calcined at 300 °C during 180 min, using a continuous-flow quartz tubular reactor employing 50 cm3 min−1 of different gases (air, N2, Ar) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The activation of the solids was carried out in the same reactor under a continuous H2 flow (50 cm3 min−1) at 400 °C for 90 min. 2.2 Characterization of the support and catalysts The textural characterization of the support and catalysts was performed by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument. The experiments were conducted at −196 °C with an approximate sample mass of 100 mg. Prior to the measurements, the samples were dried in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h to remove moisture and degassed in situ. The textural characterization included measurements of specific surface area (SBET), total pore volume (Vp), micropore volume (Vmicro), and specific surface area of micropores (Smicro). The specific surface area was determined according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) isotherm model. The total pore volume was calculated from the total N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.99. The micropore surface area and volume were estimated using the t-plot method. The total number of acid sites and the acid strength of the support were determined using potentiometric titration. In each experiment, 50 mg of solid sample was suspended in 45 cm³ of acetonitrile (Cicarelli) and stirred for 3 h. Then, titration was performed using a 0.05 n-butylamine (Carlo Erba) solution at a rate of 0.05 cm3 min−1. The variation in electrode potential was measured using a digital pH meter with a dual-function electrode (Instrumentalia S.R.L). The nature of the acidic sites of the support was determined via the isopropanol (IPA) decomposition test reaction. The experiments were conducted in a fixed-bed continuous-flow reactor between 200 and 300 °C under atmospheric pressure, with an IPA feed of 4.5 %v/v in helium and a flow rate of 40 cm3 min−1. The acidic group content in the support was determined using Boehm titration. This technique quantifies the concentration of carboxylic, lactonic, and phenolic groups in a carbon-based material, assuming that NaHCO3 neutralizes carboxylic groups, Na2CO3 neutralizes carboxylic and lactonic groups, and NaOH neutralizes carboxylic, lactonic, and phenolic groups. For this purpose, 500 mg of sample was added to 30 cm3 of each 0.025 mol L −1 basic solution: NaHCO3, Na2CO3, and NaOH. The solutions were titrated according to the standard procedure for this technique [40,41]. The Ni metal content was determined using an atomic absorption spectrophotometer (AA-6650 Shimadzu). Samples were analyzed in duplicate using a certified standard. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed using a TGA Q50 V20.13. Build 39 instrument. In each experiment, approximately 10 mg of dried and degassed sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a continuous flow of 100 cm3 min−1 of air (≥ 99.5 %, Linde), N2 (≥ 99.995 %, Air Liquid) or Ar (≥ 99.999 %, Linde), depending on the analysis. The gases released at different stages of the experiment were analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) in the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1 (Resolution 4, 32 scans). Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analyses were conducted in a quartz tubular reactor equipped with an electric furnace, thermocouple, and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to each analysis, the samples were purged with a continuous N2 flow of 20 cm3 min−1. For each test, 50 mg of sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of 20 cm3 min−1 of N2 (90 %) - H2 (10 %). The consumption of H2 was quantified for the reduction of Ni+2 species and the degree of reducibility was calculated for all catalysts. To do this, a calibration curve was created using mixtures of the support (SC) with different amounts of NiO. First, the theoretical H2 consumption was calculated for the samples with different amounts of NiO, considering that 1 mol of H2 is consumed for every 1 mol of Ni. Finally, the degree of reducibility (R %) was calculated from the quotient between the moles of H2 consumed measured in the TPR test with respect to the moles of H2 consumed according to the Ni content determined by AAS. X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization of the catalysts was performed using a Philips 3020 powder diffractometer with a PW 3710 controller, which was equipped with a sealed tube emitting Cu K radiation with a Ni filter (40 kV-20 mA). The identification of crystalline phases was carried out based on literature data. For the reduced catalysts, the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)) was employed to estimate the average crystallite size (dXRD). (1) d XRD = K . λ B . cos ( θ ) where K = 0.89, λ = 0.15418 nm, B (rad) is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the peak corresponding to the (111) plane of metallic Ni, and θ (rad) is the angle measured at the center of the peak. Hydrogen chemisorption measurements were performed using a dynamic system equipped with a TCD detector. The samples were reduced in H2 at 400 °C for 90 min, purged with Ar for 2 h at 400 °C, and then cooled to room temperature under Ar flow. Subsequently, hydrogen pulses were injected until saturation. The metal dispersions were estimated from the amount of hydrogen consumed, assuming an H/Ni adsorption stoichiometry of 1. From the metal dispersion (D), the average Ni particle size (d) was calculated using Eq. (2): (2) d = 6 . V m D . A m where Vm is the atomic volume of Ni (0.01094 nm3) and Am is the surface area of a Ni atom (0.0676 nm2). 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The liquid-phase glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction was conducted in a batch reactor (Berghof BR 100) equipped with a manometer, two thermocouples, gas and liquid sampling ports, and an electric temperature controller with magnetic stirring (1000 rpm). All experiments were performed using analytical-grade glycerol solutions (99.99 wt. %, Anedra). After adding the catalyst to the glycerol solution, the reactor was purged three times with N₂ to remove air and then pressurized with H2 to the initial operative pressure. The reaction temperature was set, and once reached, stirring was initiated at 1000 rpm, marking time zero for the reaction. Gas-phase products were analyzed using a Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD and a Hayesep D 100–120 column. The liquid-phase products were analyzed using a Shimadzu GCMS-QP5050A gas chromatograph equipped with an HP PONA 19091S-001 capillary column (50 m) and both FID and MS detectors. (9) C ( % ) = total moles of carbon in products 3 . initial moles of glycerol . 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Support characterization Table 1 summarizes the textural and acid-base properties of the support. The textural characterization results indicate that the support exhibits an SBET of ∼200 m2 g⁻¹, with Smeso/Smicro and Vmeso/Vmicro ratios of ∼2.78 and ∼23 respectively, suggesting that the material is primarily mesoporous, with a low contribution of micropores. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm for the SC support (Figure S1, Supplementary Information) corresponds to a type IV isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop, according to the IUPAC classification [42]. This isotherm is characteristic of mesoporous materials, while the hysteresis loop is associated with materials with slit-type pores. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patter for the SC support. As can be seen, the broad peak between 15° and 30° indicates the presence of amorphous silica, while the peak at 21.8° is assigned to the tridymite phase of SiO2 (∆) (JCPDS 18–1170). The peaks at 26.4°, 35.7°, 60.0° and 71.9° are assigned to the (0 1 1), (1 1 1), (2 2 0), and (3 1 1) planes of silicon carbide (▲) (JCPDS 22–1316). It can also be observed that there is a broad peak around 43.7°, which is assigned to the (1 0 0) plane of hexagonal graphitic carbon (□) (JCPDS 25–284). Regarding acid-base properties, the potentiometric titration technique allows for the determination of the number of surface acidic sites (NS) and their average acidity strength, based on the following initial potential ranges: Ei > 100 mV (very strong sites), 0 < Ei < 100 mV (strong sites), −100 < Ei < 0 mV (weak sites), and Ei < −100 mV (very weak sites) [43]. The results, showed in Table 1, reveal that the SC support presents strong acidic sites (Ei = 12.6 mV) with NS = 0.18 mmol g −1. The nature of these acidic sites was investigated using the isopropanol (IPA) decomposition reaction. This reaction has been described as an indirect measure for characterizing the acid-base properties of a solid sample. According to the obtained results, the sites can be classified based on their ability to dehydrate or dehydrogenate isopropanol, leading to the formation of propylene, diisopropyl ether (DIPE), and water via dehydration, or the formation of acetone and hydrogen via dehydrogenation. When propylene and DIPE are produced, the surface sites are Lewis acidic or basic. When propylene and acetone are produced, the surface sites may be Lewis acidic or basic. If the only reaction product is propylene, the sites may be strong Lewis or Brønsted acidic sites [44]. Table 1 shows the selectivity results for propylene, acetone, and DIPE obtained for the SC support at 300 °C for an IPA conversion of 14 %. As can be observed, the main reaction products are propylene and acetone, indicating that the SC support contains Lewis acidic and basic sites. Bedia et al. determined that in the presence of acidic carbons, isopropanol decomposition reaction yields only propylene and water as reaction products by dehydration, while in presence of carbons with basic surface acetone is obtained with high selectivity (> 80 %) [45]. In our case, since the selectivity to propylene is greater than the selectivity to acetone, it could be inferred that the material presents a greater contribution of acidic sites than basic ones. Since the support is a composite of SiO2 and C, the presence of SiO2 may affect the acid-base properties of the support. Gervasini et al. found that in absence of any modifier, the SiO2 material produces only propylene as reaction product, but with low reaction rate, indicating the presence of both weak acid and basic sites, revealing its amphoteric behaviour [44]. Based on these results, SiO2 is considered a relatively neutral material composed of siloxane (Si-O-Si) and silanol (Si-OH) groups, so the presence of surface sites in C would account for the observed acidity. In this regard, the Bohem titration technique allows for the determination of the functional groups present in the carbonaceous portion of the support, classifying them as carboxylic, phenolic, and lactonic. According to the results presented in Table 1, the support mainly contains carboxylic groups, which are the strongest acidic groups. This result is consistent with those obtained by potentiometric titration. It can also be observed that the total number of acidic sites exceeds the total number of basic sites, which agrees with the results obtained in the IPA decomposition test reaction. 3.2 Catalysts characterization The decomposition profiles of the Ni/SC catalyst precursors, previously prepared by impregnation and dried in an oven at 105 °C for 12 h, were determined through in situ TGA-FTIR analysis. These analyses were carried out in the temperature range of 25 °C to 800 °C in the same atmospheres used during the calcination treatments, namely air, N2, and Ar. Simultaneously, the gases resulting from the thermal decomposition were analyzed using FTIR spectroscopy. Fig. 2 shows the TGA/DTG profiles for the Ni(Cl−)/SC, Ni(Ac−)/SC, and Ni(NO3 −)/SC catalysts. Meanwhile, Fig. 3 presents the FTIR spectra in terms of absorbance for the gases collected during decomposition; the results are shown as a function of temperature and wavenumber (2D plot) and as a function of testing time and wavenumber (3D surface plot), where the relationship between time and temperature is established through the heating ramp. Fig. 2(a) shows the TGA/DTG profiles for Ni(Cl−)/SC in air, N2, and Ar atmospheres. As observed, two characteristic peaks appear in all three atmospheres. The first peak, occurring between 50 °C and 150 °C, corresponds to the loss of water molecules, representing 3 % of the total sample mass. The second event, observed between 400 °C and 650 °C, is primarily associated with the decomposition of the precursor. This mass loss accounts for 12 % in an Ar atmosphere and increases to 32 % in air and N₂ atmospheres. The difference in values could be attributed to the gasification of the support in air and N₂ atmospheres. Figure S2 shows the TGA/DTG profiles for the SC support in the three atmospheres. As it can been seen in the Ar atmosphere the gasification of the support is negligible. The decomposition of NiCl2·6H2O in the catalyst accounts for approximately 13 %, while the carbon content in the SC support represents 25 % [39]. The total mass losses amount to 15 % in an Ar atmosphere and 35 % in air and N2 atmospheres. These results suggest that the decomposition of NiCl2·6H2O proceeds without gasification of the support in an Ar atmosphere, whereas in air and N₂ atmospheres, it occurs simultaneously with the gasification of the support. To validate the proposed hypotheses, FTIR spectra of the gases collected during decomposition in the three atmospheres were analyzed, as shown in Figs. 3(a), (b), and (c). Table 2 presents the bands associated with the chemical species identified in the decomposition of each precursor under different treatment atmospheres, along with the corresponding temperature range and the mass loss determined by TGA/DTG at that moment. The results in Table 2 confirm the presence of adsorbed water between 50 °C and 150 °C, as well as coordinated water molecules between 400 °C and 650 °C, which are associated with the dehydration of NiCl2·6H2O (Eq. (10)). (10) NiC l 2 . 6 H 2 O → NiC l 2 + 6 H 2 O Popescu et al. determined that the decomposition of NiCl2·6H2O salt proceeds according to Eq. (11) [46]. (11) NiC l 2 . 6 H 2 O → NiO + 2 HCl + 5 H 2 O Since the characteristic HCl band at 2800 cm−1 is not observed in the FTIR spectra, it can be inferred that NiCl2 may decompose by releasing Cl2, which is not detectable by IR. Figure S3 shows the TGA/DTG for the NiCl2·6H2O salt decomposition and the corresponding FTIR spectra. As it can be seen, the first decomposition stage corresponds to the release of the 6 H2O molecules (45 wt. %), while the second stage would ascribe to the NiCl2 decomposition (55 wt. %). In this scenario, Ni would likely remain interacting with species from the support, probably as Ni2+ (Eq. (12)). (12) NiC l 2 → Ni + 2 + Cl 2 + 2 e − For the case of decomposition in air and N2 atmospheres, an intense band at 2350 cm−1 is observed between 400 °C and 650 °C, characteristic of CO2. While the presence of this band at low temperature is associated with atmospheric CO2, its appearance at high temperatures could indicate the decomposition of the SC support by gasification, a result that matches the mass losses obtained by TGA/DTG. Fig. 2(b) shows the TGA/DTG profiles for Ni(Ac−)/SC in air, N2, and Ar atmospheres. In this case, the decomposition follows a similar pattern in all three atmospheres, presenting three main events: the first between 50 °C and 150 °C, the second between 200 °C and 400 °C, and the third between 350 °C and 650 °C. The first event corresponds to the loss of surface-adsorbed water, which represents 3 % by weight of the total mass in all cases. The second event is associated with the decomposition of the metal precursor, with mass losses in the range of 6–8 %. Finally, the third event is linked to the decomposition of the support, with mass losses of 16 % in the Ar atmosphere and 23–24 % in air and N₂ atmospheres. This indicates a total mass loss of 25 % in the Ar atmosphere and 33–35 % in air and N₂. When observing the temperature of the peak at which the support gasification occurs, the following pattern is obtained: 460 °C (air) < 525 °C (N₂) < 575 °C (Ar). This indicates that decomposition in an inert atmosphere delays the gasification of the support. The FTIR spectra of the gases collected for Ni(Ac−)/SC in air, N₂, and Ar atmospheres are shown in Figs. 3(c), (d), and (e). As with Ni(Cl−)/SC, the presence of the characteristic water and CO2 bands are observed, as indicated in Table 2. Starting from 200 °C in air and N2 atmospheres, and from 300 °C in the Ar atmosphere, bands characteristic of CH3COOH (Table 2) are also observed. The presence of these bands would indicate the decomposition of the metal precursor according to Eq. (13). In this regard, De Jesus et al. reported the presence of H2O and CH3COOH during the decomposition of Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O [47]. (13) Ni ( C H 3 COO ) . 4 H 2 O → NiO + 2 C H 3 COOH + 3 H 2 O For Ni(NO₃−)/SC, Fig. 2(c) shows the TGA/DTG profiles in air, N₂, and Ar atmospheres. As can be seen, the shape of the profiles is similar to that obtained for the Ni(Ac−)/SC catalysts, displaying three weight loss events: the first between 50 °C and 150 °C, the second between 200 °C and 350 °C, and the third between 350 °C and 650 °C. The first event corresponds to the loss of adsorbed water, representing approximately 4 % by weight in all the atmospheres studied. The second event corresponds to the decomposition of the metal precursor, representing a mass loss of 6–7 %. The third event is associated with the decomposition of the SC support. This final event shows its peak at different temperatures depending on the atmosphere considered, with the decomposition occurring earlier in the presence of air, where the maximum decomposition rate is reached at 450 °C, while in the inert Ar atmosphere, the peak is found at 580 °C. The FTIR spectra of the gases collected during the decomposition of Ni(NO3⁻)/SC in air, N2, and Ar atmospheres are shown in Figs. 3(f), (g), and (h). In all cases, the characteristic bands of water and CO2 are observed (Table 2). Additionally, in all the studied atmospheres, starting from 200 °C, a band at 1550 cm−1 is observed, corresponding to NO2. The presence of this molecule is associated with the decomposition of the precursor (Eqs. (14) and 15). (14) Ni ( N O 3 ) 2 . 6 H 2 O → Ni ( N O 3 ) 2 + 6 H 2 O (15) Ni ( N O 3 ) 2 → NiO + 2 N O 2 + 1 2 O 2 These results are consistent with those reported by Mikuli et al., who determined that Ni(NO3)2·6H2O dehydrates between 56 °C and 227 °C, and the anhydrous salt decomposes around 307 °C, releasing nitrogen oxides and generating NiO as the solid product [48]. In all cases, the results of the decomposition of Ni precursors in air and N2 atmosphere are very similar. The differences are the temperature centers where the decomposition rate reaches the maximum value. In this regard, the decomposition in N2 occurs at temperatures higher than decomposition in air, but lower than decomposition temperatures in Ar. This would indicate that the decomposition in N2 has an intermediate behavior between the decompositions in air and Ar. Since the N2 used for the tests contains small traces of O2 due to its degree of purity, this could be the reason for the results obtained. To analyze the solid products obtained from the decomposition of the precursors, XRD analysis was performed on the solids calcined in air, Ar, and N₂ at 300 °C for 180 min (Fig. 4 ). In all cases, regardless of the calcination atmosphere, the peak at 21.8° is assigned to the tridymite phase of SiO2 (∆) (JCPDS 18–1170), the peaks at 26.4°, 35.7°, 60.0° and 71.9° are assigned to the silicon carbide (▲) (JCPDS 22–1316) and the broad peak around 43.7° is assigned to graphitic carbon (□). All these peaks are associate with the SC support. Fig. 4(a) shows the diffractograms for Ni(Cl−)/SC. The catalyst dried at 120 °C for 12 h displays characteristic peaks at 2θ = 15.2°, 30.0°, and 36.2°, corresponding to the precursor salt NiCl2·6H2O (●) (JCPDS 71–2032). For this catalyst, the salt peaks disappear when it is calcined at 300 °C for 180 min in Ar, air, and N₂ atmospheres, indicating that the thermal treatment enables the complete decomposition of the precursor. No peaks associated with the presence of NiO are observed in these diffractograms, suggesting that the decomposition of NiCl2 results in Ni2+ species interacting with the SC support species, as proposed based on the TGA-FTIR results. Fig. 4(b) for the Ni(Ac−)/SC dried catalyst shows peaks at 2θ = 5.9°, 8.5°, 10.4°, and 12.9° corresponding to the precursor salt Ni(CH3COO) 2·4H2O (■) (JCPDS 01–0105). These peaks disappear in the calcined catalysts, indicating that the thermal treatments are effective in decomposing the precursor. In this condition, the presence of peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.2°, and 62.8° would indicate the presence of the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes of NiO (★) (JCPDS 47–1049), which is consistent with the TGA-FTIR results for the decomposition of Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O. A particular situation arises for the sample calcined in N2 at 300 °C, where a peak at 2θ = 44.4° is observed, corresponding to the (1 1 1) plane of Ni3N (♦) (JCPDS 10–0280). The formation of this species is due to the reaction between the NiO formed from the decomposition of the metal precursor and the N2 present in the calcination atmosphere (Eq. (16)). (16) 6 NiO + N 2 → 2 N i 3 N + 3 O 2 Fig. 4(c) shows, for the dried catalyst, peaks at 2θ = 13°, 18.2°, 18.6°, 20.2°, and 30.8°, indicating the presence of the precursor salt Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (▼) (JCPDS 22–0751). These peaks are absent in the calcined samples, indicating the effective decomposition of the precursor. In the particular case of calcination in air, peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.2°, and 62.8° are observed, corresponding to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes of NiO (★) (JCPDS 47–1049), which is consistent with the TGA-FTIR results for the decomposition of the precursor. As observed for Ni(Ac−)/SC, calcination in a N2 atmosphere at 300 °C generates a peak at 2θ = 44.4°, corresponding to the (1 1 1) plane of Ni3N (♦) (JCPDS 10–0280). A temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was conducted on the calcined catalysts to determine the activation temperature. The resulting profiles are shown in Fig. 5 . For the Ni(Cl−)/SC and Ni(Ac−)/SC catalysts, two main H2 consumption events are observed: the first between 300 °C and 450 °C, and the second between 475 °C and 625 °C. The literature reports several ways in which Ni interacts with silica-based supports. In the range of 280–300 °C, the reduction of Ni2+ species with weak interaction with the support occurs; these are surface species that exist as segregated phases. Between 300–400 °C, the reduction of Ni2+ species with moderate interaction with the support takes place. Finally, between 600–700 °C, the reduction of Ni2+ species with strong interaction with the support occurs, which is the case for the formation of nickel hydrosilicates [49,50]. For the Ni(Cl−)/SC and Ni(Ac−)/SC catalysts, the first event corresponds to the reduction of Ni2+species with moderate interaction with the support, but the second event does not correspond to a metal reduction event. In this temperature range, the H2 consumption is accompanied by the release of CO, CO2, and CH4, indicating the gasification of the SC support. Regarding the shape of the peaks, the profiles for Ni(Cl−)/SC calcined in the three atmospheres are similar, suggesting the same type of metal-support interaction. In the case of Ni(Ac−)/SC, the shape of the peaks depends on the calcination atmosphere. In Ar, the first peak is much sharper than in N2 and air, where it takes on a plateau-like shape. This suggests that the metal-support interaction is stronger in air and N2 than in Ar. For the Ni(NO3 −)/SC catalysts, the two events of H2 consumption overlap, indicating that the reduction of Ni+2 species and support gasification occur simultaneously. Regarding peak shape, the presence of plateau-like profiles would indicate greater metal-support interaction with respect to the other precursors. In order to determine the H2 consumption corresponding to the reduction of Ni+2 species, the region between 300 °C and 450 °C was considered. The degree of reduction for all catalysts was close to 92–99 % (Table 4), indicating that all Ni+2 species present in the catalysts can be completely reduced to Ni0. Based on these results, the catalysts were activated in a hydrogen flow (50 cm3 min−1) at 400 °C for 90 min. This temperature was chosen to ensure the complete reduction of all Ni species present in the calcined catalysts while preventing support gasification. The textural characterization results obtained from N2 adsorption-desorption for the calcined and reduced Ni/SC catalysts are presented in Table 3 . The results indicate that all Ni/SC catalysts exhibit similar textural properties, regardless of the precursor used or the calcination atmosphere. The specific surface area ranges from 200 to 220 m2 g−1, while the total pore volume is approximately 0.40 cm3 g−1. The minor contribution of micropores to the total pore volume classifies these catalysts as mesoporous, with type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops according to IUPAC (Figure S4, Supplementary Information). In all cases, the addition of Ni to the SC support does not lead to pore blockage, as no decrease in specific surface area is observed. The metal content, dispersion, degree of reduction and particle and crystallite sizes of the reduced catalysts are presented in Table 4 . The Ni metal content of the reduced catalysts was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS). The results, shown in Table 4, indicate that in all cases the measured content is close to the nominal content (∼ 5 wt. %). In terms of metal dispersion, differences are observed depending on the precursor used for the preparation, following the trend Ni(NO3 −)/SC (33–51 %) > Ni(Cl−)/SC (7–9 %) > Ni(Ac−)/SC (6–9 %). This results in particle sizes between 11 and 17 nm for Ni(Ac−)/SC, between 10 and 12 nm for Ni(Cl−)/SC and between 1.9 nm and 2.9 nm for Ni(NO3 −)/SC. It is noteworthy that the Ni(Cl−)/SC catalysts have very similar particle sizes regardless of the calcination atmosphere, which is in agreement with the similarity of the TPR profiles obtained for these catalysts. In the case of Ni(Ac−)/SC, calcination in air produces the smallest particle sizes, while calcination in Ar produces the largest particle sizes, maintaining the relationship with the metal-support interaction inferred by TPR. The Ni(NO3 −)/SC catalysts, on the other hand, show the highest dispersions and therefore the smallest particle sizes. These results are in agreement with the higher metal-support interaction determined by TPR. To analyze the state of the metallic Ni phase and the structure of the calcined and reduced catalysts, XRD analyses were performed. The results are shown in Fig. 6 . In all cases, regardless of the calcination atmosphere, the peak at 21.8° is assigned to the tridymite phase of SiO2 (∆) (JCPDS 18–1170) and the peaks at 26.4°, 35.7°, 60.0° and 71.9° are assigned to the silicon carbide (▲) (JCPDS 22–1316). All these peaks are associate with the SC support. Furthermore, the peaks at 44.4°, 51.7° and 76.3° correspond to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) planes of the cubic phase of nickel metal (▽) (JCPDS 04–0850). No peaks corresponding to NiO or Ni precursor salts are observed in any of the diffractograms, indicating that the activation of the catalysts in all cases results in the reduction of the Ni+2 species to Ni0. From the peak at 44.4° for metallic Ni, crystal sizes were calculated using the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)). The fits of the main peak are shown in Supplementary Information (Figure S5). As shown in Table 3, the crystal sizes are slightly larger than the corresponding particle sizes. For the Ni(Cl−)/SC catalysts, the shape of the peaks at 44.4° is similar for all pretreatments, resulting in similar crystal sizes between 11.7 and 13.8 nm. For Ni(Ac−)/SC the crystal sizes are between 12.1 and 19.1 nm, following the trend observed for H2 chemisorption as a function of calcination atmosphere. In the case of Ni(NO3 −)/SC catalysts, the crystal sizes could not be estimated due to the poor definition of the main peak corresponding to metallic Ni. The presence of diffuse peaks indicates the presence of small particle sizes, confirming the results obtained by H2 chemisorption. 3.3 Catalytic activity In order to compare the activity of the catalysts prepared from the different precursors and calcined under different conditions, reaction tests were carried out at 220 °C, initial 2 MPa H2 (5.5 MPa autogenous pressure) and 2 h, using aqueous solutions of 10 wt. % of analytical glycerol (99.9 %, Cicarelli) and a catalyst/glycerol mass ratio (mc/mgly) of 0.24. The results are shown in Table 5 . All catalysts are active in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol with total conversions between 5 % and 10 %, with low conversion to gaseous products (< 1 %), mainly CH4 and CO2. In all cases the carbon balance was ∼ 98 %. This is remarkable when compared to other noble metal based catalytic systems such as Ru [51,52] or Pt [53,54], which have a high capacity for CC bond cleavage. The liquid products identified and quantified were C1: methanol (MeOH), C2: ethanol (EtOH) and ethylene glycol (EG), and C3: 1-propanol (1-POH), acetol (AcOH) and 1,2-propylene glycol (1,2-PG). Selectivity results indicate the preference of Ni catalysts for the production of 1,2-PG, with selectivity values in the range of 80–90 %. Similar selectivity values (77–80 %) have been reported for Ni/C catalysts at 200 °C and 5 MPa H2 with mc/mgly ratios of 0.19 [33] and Ni/NaX catalysts at 200 °C and 6 MPa H2 with mc/mgly ratios of 5 [37]. In addition, all catalysts show low selectivity towards AcOH, an intermediate in the production of 1,2-PG, which is difficult to achieve at low conversion rates using metal phases that have a tendency to break CO bonds. For the remaining products, all catalysts show low selectivity towards C1 (MeOH) and C2 (EtOH, EG) products. For all Ni/SC catalysts, the ability of Ni to participate in CO bond cleavage reactions is evident due to its high electron density. In the presence of low-acid supports, the catalytic activity depends exclusively on the structure and particle size of the Ni metal phase. An example of a catalytic system where this phenomenon occurs is Ni/SiO2 [34,55]. Since all the catalysts were prepared on the basis of the SC support with similar Ni metal contents, the differences lie in the effect of the type of metal precursor and the atmospheres used for calcination on the Ni particle size. In order to correlate the intrinsic activity of the catalysts as a function of metal precursor and calcination atmosphere, the TOFG and TOF1,2-PG results presented in Table 5 were correlated as a function of metal particle size (Fig. 7 ). As can be seen, there is a linear correlation between both TOF values and particle size. For glycerol conversion the linear correlation is established with r2 = 0.96, while for 1,2-PG formation r2 = 0.97. These results show that an increase in particle size leads to an increase in the rate of glycerol conversion, and particularly the rate of 1,2-PG formation. Vasiliadou et al. showed that for Cu/SiO2 catalysts, the initial TOF values at 1 h, calculated at 240 °C and 8 MPa H2, increase from 300 h−1 to 500 h−1 as the average Cu particle size increases from ∼10 nm to ∼23 nm; the high TOF values are a consequence of the conversions achieved (30–50 %) due to the intrinsic CO bond breaking capacity of Cu and the operating temperature. The authors attributed these results to the change in the electronic properties of the metal particles, resulting in a higher adsorption of the glycerol molecules [56]. Similar results were reported for Ru/SBA-15 catalysts prepared by impregnation and reduced in H2 and evaluated at 160 °C and 8 MPa H2, where the TOF values showed a decrease from 850 h−1 to 37 h−1 as the metal dispersion increased from 0.6 % to 37 % [57]. Our results indicate that the highest TOF values are obtained using Ni(Cl−)/SC calcined in Ar, while the use of Ni(NO3 −)/SC calcined in any of the three atmospheres leads to the lowest TOF values. The Ni(NO3 −)/SC precursor decomposes into NiO species with a higher metal-support interaction than the other precursors. Its reduction leads to Ni metal particles of small size, around 2 nm, which would be responsible for the low TOF values obtained. Regarding the Ni(Cl−)/SC precursor, its calcination produces Ni+2 species with moderate interaction with the support, without passing through NiO. The metallic particle size by the reduction of these species would be responsible for the high TOF values obtained, particularly in an Ar atmosphere. The Ni(Ac-)/SC catalysts, on the other hand, show an intermediate behavior between Ni(NO3 −)/SC and Ni(Cl−)/SC. Their calcination in any of the three atmospheres also generates NiO species which are reduced to Ni metal particles with particle sizes intermediate between Ni(Cl−)/SC and Ni(NO3 −)/SC. Correlation of TOF results with Ni particle size indicates that glycerol hydrogenolysis over Ni catalysts is a structurally sensitive reaction. These results are consistent with the need for large Ni metal particles for glycerol hydrogenolysis. 4 Conclusions In this work, Ni catalysts supported on a SiO2 C (SC) composite were prepared using NiCl2·6H2O, Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O as precursors and different calcination atmospheres, with the aim of studying their structure and applying them in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol in the liquid phase. The results showed that the decomposition of the precursor salts occurs completely at 300 °C, irrespective of the calcination atmosphere (Ar, air or N2). The decomposition of NiCl2·6H2O on the support produces Ni+2 species, while the decomposition of Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O produces NiO. In all cases the Ni+2 species show moderate interaction with the support and are reduced to Ni0 by activation in H2 flow at 400 °C. All reduced catalysts were active in the hydrogenolysis reaction with selectivity values of 80–90 % to 1,2-propylene glycol, the main liquid product. In all cases, low conversions to gases and low selectivity to C1 and C2 products such as methanol, ethanol and ethylene glycol were obtained. The choice of metal precursor and calcination atmosphere affects the metal particle size and thus the activity values obtained. It was possible to establish a linear correlation between TOF values based on glycerol conversion and 1,2-propylene glycol production with particle size. The highest TOF values are obtained using Ni(Cl−)/SC calcined in Ar, whereas the use of Ni(NO3 −)/SC calcined in any of the three atmospheres gives the lowest TOF values. coredata.dc:description: In this work, Ni catalysts supported on a SiO2 C (SC) material were prepared using different metal precursors (NiCl2·6H2O, Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) and calcination atmospheres (Ar, air and N2), to be applied in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol in liquid phase. The thermal decomposition of the precursors was studied by in situ TGA-FTIR, XRD and TPR, which allowed the determination of the Ni species formed and their degree of interaction with the support. After activation in H2 flow, the reduced catalysts were characterized by XRD and H2 chemisorption, which allowed the determination of their crystalline structure and particle size. All catalysts showed activity in the hydrogenolysis reaction with high selectivity to 1,2-propylene glycol (80–90 %) and low selectivity to CC bond cleavage products. The type of precursor and calcination atmosphere were found to influence Ni dispersion and Turnover Frequency (TOF) values, obtaining a correlation between catalytic activity and metal particle size. The results show that the TOF increases with increasing Ni particle size in the range of 2 to 17 nm. These results suggest that the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over Ni catalysts is a structure sensitive reaction.
